bibl.title: Letter from Cornelia Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 4, 1952

div1.p: Mrs. Kean recommends using a public relations man to counteract the Cuban press. She encloses a letter of approval from herself to Hench praising his yellow fever history work.

div1.head: Letter from Cornelia Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 4, 1952

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
4 August 1952

div1.p:
Your letter and the recordings of
a difficult situation came this
morning. I wrote an outline of the
“one sentence” letter of approval
to you. Then I called up Colonel Siler
to ask him to edit for me. He has
been ill with a virus infection, but
said he would telephone his Secretary
to mail your letter to him. I
had wanted to ask General Love's
help, but his name was not on your
“Confidential” List.

It is a shame that you should have
all these bitter questions to meet.

Have you a Public Relations man?
we have a neighbor, who represents
a Steel Co., an Oil Co., an AirLine,
& another Co. He was a newspaper man
on Gen. Eisenhomer's staff, is a friend
of Gen. Bedell Smith, head of the C. I. A.
He and his wife were devoted to
General Kean and have been kind to me. He is
a Democrat. He publishes a News Letter
which I enclose. I don't mean to suggest
him. But some good Public Relations to
Counteract the Cuban Press. Don't think
me a wicked woman, I learned this from
Rockefeller's, etc.! How about the Roceffeler Public
Relations. Dr. Sawyer & Soper?

I enclose a crude note- Please edit it
& Correct it to be what you would like-
